content.description: This climb ascends the overhanging cobbly wall 30 right of the prominent crack line of Pinigigi and start is just left of big tree. Only 25ish feet but every move is slightly over your head except maybe last 3ft pull.  Small sharp rails and cobbly holds here and there!
content.protection: None. TR only or High Ball bouldering. Great sandy flat landings for pads though.
content.location: This climb ascends the overhanging cobbly wall 30 right of the prominent crack line of Pinigigi and start is just left of big tree.

climbs.name: Pinagigi
climbs.fa: ???? Don't know for sure... Doesn't matter

content.description: 30.25 ft (Ha!) splitter crack.  5.10 with a sequence of somewhat painful finger locks through the overhanging crux.
content.protection: Big knuckle sized stoppers and cams.
content.location: Forbidden Rocks on the main wall section left most looking up at wall.  Super obvious and hard to miss as you walk under while walking in to area.

content.description: Boulder up and over bulge that makes up highest point of mega boulder I am calling "Red Horn".
content.location: This is found on one of the 2 fabulous mega blocks to be found at Forbidden Rocks spot, this one being called Red Horn (western block) and the other called Bear Clan (eastern block).  There is a obvious high point on the eastern exposure of Red Horn that this climb tackles.

content.description: Pretty fun.. seemingly the line to do here from what we saw, so get after it.Start sitting with a pinch for the left and a cobble-like undercling.  Climb out the steepness up and right.
content.location: On pillar/boulder just below the main wall and facing west.

content.description: Tucked low on a hillside in the Sauk Prairie Recreation Area. There is a 20-25 foot wall and several boulders. Great area to hang out for the day.The rock here is unique.  It is formed from shattered Barabook quartzite, that was tumbled and then re-cemented together with quartzite sand.  This matrix then mostly metamorphosed, formed a really solid chunk with an appearance similar to a conglomerate.Figuring out how to climb the routes and problems here is an experience much like learning to read Braille - your sense of touch is just as important as your sense of sight.  Enjoy!For most of the decades there has been climbing at Devils Lake, this area was either private farm land or the Badger Ammunition Plant.  Only recently was the Ammunition Plant de-commissioned and divided between the Ho-chunk Nation, the USDA, and the WDNR.  As such, there is little climbing history here.
